--- title: "Statistical Concepts" --- ::: callout-note ::: ::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-1_77af6fb920fcb959094daab06b38c4c0'} ```{.r .cell-code} random_vars<-readRDS("C:/Users/mouni/Downloads/Causal_Data_Science_Data/Causal_Data_Science_Data/random_vars.rds") ``` ::: ::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-2_6dc28b640d3199322d344690f956b7bd'} ```{.r .cell-code} View(random_vars) ``` ::: 1. ::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-3_cdbd8ae9287cb800979c4c2ea3f7705c'} ```{.r .cell-code} mean(random_vars$age) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> [1] 33.471 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} mean(random_vars$income) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> [1] 3510.731 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} var(random_vars) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> age income #> age 340.6078 29700.15 #> income 29700.1468 8625645.84 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} var(random_vars$income) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> [1] 8625646 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} sd(random_vars$age) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> [1] 18.45556 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} sd(random_vars$income) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> [1] 2936.945 ``` ::: ::: 2. Standard deviation is the square root of the variance and provides a measure of the average distance of data points from the mean. Comparing standard deviations makes sense when the variables are on similar scales. Higher standard deviations indicate greater variability. 3. ::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-4_7f4e30f16d962b6fdf3423beb480245c'} ```{.r .cell-code} cov(random_vars) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> age income #> age 340.6078 29700.15 #> income 29700.1468 8625645.84 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} cor(random_vars) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` #> age income #> age 1.0000000 0.5479432 #> income 0.5479432 1.0000000 ``` ::: ::: 4.Correlation is often easier to interpret as it is scaled between -1 and 1, making it independent of the scale of the variables. It indicates the strength and direction of a linear relationship. Covariance is in the units of the product of the two variables, making it sensitive to the scales. 5. ::: {.cell hash='02_statistics_cache/html/unnamed-chunk-5_11ba61fec67c645b4720819af6710fbd'} ```{.r .cell-code} aggregate(income ~ (age<=18), data=random_vars,FUN=mean) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} aggregate(income ~ (age>=18 & age<=65), data=random_vars,FUN=mean) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} aggregate(income ~ (age>=65), data=random_vars,FUN=mean) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: :::
